person_022.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
person_022.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

person_020.name: NehemiahGrew
person_020.description: English plant anatomist and physiologist, known as the 'Father of Plant Anatomy'. FRSL.

person_1080.name: AntoineParent
person_1080.description: French mathematician and physicist who published on a range of subjects including botany.

person_021.name: StephenHales
person_021.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

person_024.name: Thomas AndrewKnight
person_024.description: Knight was a botanist and horticulturalist. He was the second president of the Royal Horticulture Society. Davy frequently fished on Knight's esates in the Welsh Marches. FRSL.

person_1054.name: Abū MūsāJābir ibn Ḥayyān
person_1054.description: the purported author of a large number of works in Arabic, often called the Jabirian corpus. His name is often latinized to Gebir or Geber.

person_059.name: Giovanni AgostinoPantheo
person_059.description: Venetian alchemist and priest who attempted to distinguish alchemy (which he described as changing the surface appearance of things) from archemy (an ancient science with biblical roots).

person_061.name: AlbertusMagnus
person_061.description: Wrote on natural philosophy. alchemy and much else besides. Bishop of Regensburg (Ratisbon), 1260-1262 and from 1931 a Doctor of the Church

person_062.name: GeorgiusAgricola
person_062.description: Physician who studied the minerals and mining practices in Saxony and surrounding areas. His influential book De re metallica (1556) was published postumously.

person_071.name: JamesFreake
person_071.description: Seventeenth-century translator of Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa.

person_072.name: JacquesGirard
person_072.description: Sixteenth-century alchemist and translator (into French) of Roger Bacon.

person_460.name: GerolamoCardano
person_460.description: Italian polymath and writer whose interests included mathematics, medicine, natural philosophy, alchemy, astrology, astronomy and philosophy.

person_744.name: AndreaCesalpino
person_744.description: Florentine physician, philosopher, and botanist. In his works he classified plants according to their fruits and seeds, rather than alphabetically or by medicinal properties.

person_370.name: AndreasLibavius
person_370.description: German physician and alchemist and chemist.

person_623.name: OleBorch
person_623.description: Danish royal physician who taught Nicolas Steno.

person_746.name: BernardTrevisan
person_746.description: Fictional Italian alchemist constructed by later alchemists.

person_747.name: Charles VIII
person_747.description: Charles the Affable. King of France from 1483 to death, known as Charles the Affable.

person_1108.name: Giovanni AurelioAugurello
person_1108.description: Italian humanist scholar, poet and alchemist

person_1099.name: RicardusAnglicus
person_1099.description: Richardus Anglicus the alchemist wrote several texts in the 14th century, including Correctorium alchemiae, also known as Corrector (fatuorum). He was considered among the leading English alchemists of the period.

person_1092.name: Arnaldusde Villa Nova
person_1092.description: A physician and a religious reformer. He is credited with translating a number of medical texts from Arabic, including works by Ibn Sina Avicenna, Abu-l-Salt, and Galen.

person_754.name: JohnDee
person_754.description: English mathematician, astronomer, astrologer, teacher, occultist and alchemist. He was the court astronomer for, and advisor to, Elizabeth I.

person_692.name: ThomasAquinas
person_692.description: Italian Dominican friar and priest, an influential philosopher and theologian, and a jurist in the tradition of scholasticism from the county of Aquino in the Kingdom of Sicily. Thomas was a prominent proponent of natural theology and the father of a school of thought known as Thomism.

person_1110.name: Giambatistadella Porta
person_1110.description: Author of "Magia Naturalis", he was nicknamed "Baptista Porta" by Libavius.

person_509.name: Paracelsus
person_509.description: Born Theophrastus von Hohenheim Swiss physician, alchemist, lay theologian, and philosopher of the German Renaissance.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_306.name: AthanasiusKircher
person_306.description: Prolific German Jesuit scholar and polymath who published many book, including on geology.

person_423.name: Johann vonLöwenstern-Kunckel
person_423.description: German/Swedish chemist and apothecary. Later director of the laboratory and glass works of Brandenburg.

person_1093.name: PedaniusDioscorides
person_1093.description: "the father of pharmacognosy", was a Greek physician, pharmacologist, botanist, and author of De materia medica a 5-volume Greek encyclopedic pharmacopeia on herbal medicine and related medicinal substances, that was widely read for more than 1,500 years. For almost two millennia Dioscorides was regarded as the most prominent writer on plants and plant drugs.

person_1111.name: RaymondLoully
person_1111.description: Born Ramon Llull (anglicized to Raymond Loully), he was a philosopher, theologian, poet, missionary, Christian apologist and former knight from the Kingdom of Majorca.

person_1094.name: NicolasGuibert
person_1094.description: A Franco-German physician and alchemist who later became a fierce critic of alchemy, opposing ideas on transmutation.

person_1096.name: ThomasErastus
person_1096.description: Thomas Erastus was a Swiss physician and Calvinist theologian. He published several pieces focused on medicine, astrology, alchemy, and attacked in his publications the system of Paracelsus. In doing so, he defended medieval tradition in general, and Galen in particular, while conceding some merit to specific points in Paracelsus.

person_324.name: RogerBacon
person_324.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

person_639.name: Johann RudolfGlauber
person_639.description: German-Dutch alchemist and chemist. He discovered sodium sulphate in 1625 which was named 'Glauber's salt'.

person_464.name: GeorgeRipley
person_464.description: English Augustinian canon, author, and alchemist.

person_459.name: RamonLlull
person_459.description: Catalonian philosopher, theologian, poet, missionary, Christian apologist.

person_1097.name: ChristopherPacke
person_1097.description: Packe was an English chemist who translated the works of Glauber.

person_836.name: ChristopherGlaser
person_836.description: a pharmaceutical chemist of the 17th century, the mineral glaserite is named after him.

person_814.name: Marcus AtiliusRegulus
person_814.description: Roman statesman and general who was a consul of the Roman Republic in 267 BC and 256 BC. Much of his career was spent fighting the Carthaginians during the first Punic War.

person_702.name: EdwardKelley
person_702.description: English alchemist and associate of John Dee.

person_595.name: Charles FrancisGreville
person_595.description: A British antiquarian, collector and politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1774 to 1790. FRSL.

person_015.name: William HaseldinePepys
person_015.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

person_371.name: RichardKnight
person_371.description: Brother of George who were both scientific instrument makers based in Foster Lane, Cheapside, London.

person_226.name: ThomasThomson
person_226.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

person_1100.name: JohnHampden-Trevor
person_1100.description: John Hampden-Trevor, 3rd Viscount Hampden was a British diplomat. Davy wrote a poem 'To Mr & Mrs Trevor.' in notebooks 13G and 13J which John Davy republished in Fragmentary Remains, p. 117.

person_002.name: AnnaBeddoes
person_002.description: Anna Beddoes, née Edgeworth, the wife of Thomas Beddoes who befriended Davy when he arrived in Bristol. Critics have speculated that they had an affair because Davy wrote poems to Anna and she wrote poems for him that he copied out in his notebooks.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

place_688.name: Regensburg
place_688.description: Also known as Ratisbon. Regensburg is a city in Bavaria at the confluence of the Danube, Naab, and Regen rivers.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_047.name: Donegal
place_047.description: Donegal is a town at the mouth of the River Eske, in north-west Ireland.

place_070.name: Mucrish
place_070.description: Muckish, one of the Derryveagh Mountains. See the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

place_064.name: Arakil
place_064.description: Arokil is the Errigal mountain of the same range; the handwriting on page 69 in notebook 15B was reproduced by John Davy along with the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_1392.name: Cyprus
place_1392.description: Cyprus is the third largest and third-most populous island in the Mediterranean. It is east of Greece, north of Egypt, south of Turkey, and west of Lebanon and Syria. Cyprus occupies an important role in Greek mythology, being the birthplace of Aphrodite and Adonis, and home to King Cinyras, Teucer and Pygmalion.

place_138.name: Glenarm
place_138.description: Glenarm, a village and castle in County Antrim, Northern Ireland. Davy wrote a poem called 'Glenarm', dated August 1806.

place_605.name: River Avon
place_605.description: The River Avon in central England flows generally south-westwards and is a major left-bank tributary of the River Severn.

place_914.name: River Severn
place_914.description: At 220 miles long, the longest river in Great Britain.
